I'd like to address a few points Count Otto makes. I agree completely with his comment that cross-national gun control comparisons are generally worthless. In my opinion, there are no evil little voices calling from the gun cabinet to plague American homeowners. England and the Netherlands have not avoided these sinister voices advocating gun violence by restricting guns. The people of Switzerland are not collectively so hard of hearing that they have proven immune to the subliminal demands of their guns to be loaded and unleashed on the innocent. I believe that cross-national differences have far more to do with culture than with the availability of guns.
 
 I have some experience in dealing with violent crime, and in my opinion we do not have a gun violence problem in America, we have a violence problem in general. We glorify violence in America, and we teach our young that violence is an acceptable method of resolving conflicts. Violent crime springs from a variety of motives, be it anger, hatred, envy, revenge, etc. The presence of the weapon does not give rise to the motive to use it for criminal ends. 
 
 As for why we have a RKBA, I would answer by saying I believe that the RKBA is a fundamental right of citizenship, and that it is further linked to the natural right of self defense. I can't state this position any better than Andrew Fletcher did long ago: 
 
 "And I cannot see, why arms should be denied to any man who is not a slave, since they are the only true badges of liberty. . . .The possession of arms is the distinction between a freeman and a slave. He who has nothing, and belongs to another, must be defended by him, and needs no arms: but he who thinks he is his own master, and has anything he may call his own, ought to have arms to defend himself and what he possesses, or else he lives precariously and at discretion. And though for a while those who have the sword in their power abstain from doing him injury; yet, by degrees, he will be awed into submission to every arbitrary command." Andrew Fletcher, Political Works, pp. 35 and 221 (1749).
 
 I also believe that the fundamental purpose of our criminal justice system in America is to punish the guilty without harming the innocent. I believe gun control is at odds with this principle. It seeks to punish the vast majority of the innocent out of fear of what a tiny minority might do in the future. I see it as a statement from my government that I am less a citizen and more a subject--that my government has in its wisdom decided that I can no longer be trusted with the tools to defend myself and my family from either individual or state sponsored oppression. 
 
 Could there be another burning of the Reichstag-another tyrant who seeks to take advantage of an unarmed populace to consolidate power, abrogate civil liberties, and then eliminate portions of society he dislikes? It is an interesting question Count Otto proposes. In answer, I believe that the victims of Central American government-sponsored death squads would say yes. I believe that the victims lying in the killing fields of Cambodia would agree. I believe that the victims lying in mass graves in Bosnia would agree. And I also would agree. Perhaps my life experiences have led me to be too cynical, but I do not believe that we in America have evolved beyond the petty lusts for power and dominion over our fellow man that have led to so much misery for unarmed innocents in the past. 
 
 Now could it be that my founding fathers were fallible? I cannot deny that possibility. But I believe that my Bill of Rights is the greatest declaration of individual freedoms that has ever been put to paper, and I believe these rights represent a healthy respect for the temptation man has to misuse his ability to rule others. My founding fathers entered into the covenant we call my Constitution for the express purpose of safeguarding my liberties. They could not see into the future any more than I can, but I believe they were fully aware that any government they founded had the ability to encroach upon those liberties. I believe they enshrined the several rights we see in the Bill of Rights to ensure that I possessed the means of defending my rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. As a citizen who enjoys the protections my constitution affords, I believe that the maintenance of that constitution lies in my own hands and is my responsibility. The RKBA is merely one method my founders included to ensure that I would be able to keep a good grip on the liberties they sought to bequeath to me. I do believe that an individual RKBA does offer a strong moral check on the temptations of tyrants. Is it certain that an armed populace could successfully resist a tyrant? I pray my country never has to answer this question. But I absolutely agree with the belief that without arms to defend ourselves it is certain we would prove incapable of throwing off the yoke of a tyrant:
 
 "Is it necessary for your liberty, that you should abandon those great rights by the adoption of this system?. . . Will the abandonment of your most sacred rights tend to the security of your liberty?. . . .I am fearful I have lived long enough to become an old fashioned fellow: Perhaps an invincible attachment to the dearest rights of man, may, in these refined enlightened days, be deemed old fashioned: If so, I am contented to be so. . . . Guard with jealous attention the public liberty. Suspect everyone who approaches that jewel. Unfortunately, nothing will preserve it, but downright force: Whenever you give up that force, you are inevitably ruined. . . .
 
 My great objection to this Government is, that it does not leave us the means of defending our rights; or, of waging war against tyrants. . . .
 
 The Honorable Gentleman who presides, told us, that to prevent abuses in our Government, we will assemble in Convention, recall our delegated powers, and punish our servants for abusing the trust reposed in them. Oh, Sir, we should have fine times indeed, if to punish tyrants, it were only sufficient to assemble the people. Your arms wherewith you could defend yourselves, are gone. . . . Did you ever read of any revolution in any nation, brought about by the punishment of those in power, inflicted by those who had no power at all? You read of a riot act in a country which is called one of the freest in the world, where a few neighbors cannot assemble without the risk of being shot by hired soldiery, the engines of despotism. We may see such an act in America. A standing army we shall have also, to execute the execrable commands of tyranny: And how are you to punish them? Will you order them to be punished? Who shall obey these orders? Will your Mace-bearer be a match for a disciplined regiment? In what situation are we to be? . . . .What resistance could be made? The attempt would be madness." Patrick Henry, (anti-federalist arguing against adoption of a federal constitution without a bill of rights) Speeches of June 5 and 7, 1788, before the Virginia Ratifying Convention, reprinted in The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates, pages 199-216, Mentor Books, 1986, edited by Ralph Ketchum.
 
 Finally, Count Otto asks whether the RKBA should be construed to be absolute. I say no. I tend to get in trouble sometimes from the more extreme gun rights supporters for saying this, but I say the right can be subject to limitation. The issue for me is not whether any gun control can exist, but where to strike the proper balance between public safety and respecting a fundamental individual right.

For an example of how SCOTUS has treated the absolutist argument as applied to the 1st. amendment, see the case is Konigsberg v.
